header.title: The Cloven Hoof, Issue 130
authors: Various authors; Edited by Anton Szandor LaVey and Blanche Barton

central_thesis: This issue serves as a collective tribute to Anton Szandor LaVey following his death, reaffirming his philosophical legacy, the enduring principles of LaVeyan Satanism, and the commitment of the Church of Satan to perpetuate his vision as a path of self-empowerment and pragmatic magic.

structure_content.summary: Blanche Barton provides an obituary for Anton LaVey, detailing his diverse life experiences, his founding of the Church of Satan, key publications, and recordings. It emphasizes his role in defining modern Satanism and his personal impact, concluding with his survivors and an upcoming book release.

Anton Szandor LaVey's personal account of his near-death experience in 1995. He describes experiencing absolutely nothing during the event, refuting common ideas of afterlife experiences. He uses this as a basis to advocate for valuing daily routines over waiting for a significant 'death experience'.

Christopher J. Turner praises LaVey as an inspiring figure who exemplified qualities driven out of postmodern society. He defines LaVey as an 'Aristocratic Beast,' embodying a duality of refinement and bestial carnality, and stresses the importance of continuing LaVey's 'Will to Power' against societal frailty.

structure_content.chapter_title: Anton Szandor LaVey: Meetings With a Remarkable Man
structure_content.summary: Michael Jenkins Moynihan reflects on LaVey as a misunderstood yet charming and astute figure. He highlights LaVey's ability to challenge conventional thought, presenting him as a 'shining realist' who provided 'high-voltage bullshit detectors' to those who sought truth beyond societal illusions, implying that true Satanism is subtle and profound.

structure_content.chapter_title: Anton Szandor LaVey: Supreme Creator of the Satanic Era
structure_content.summary: Mallare positions LaVey as the ultimate creator and harbinger of the Satanic Era, crediting him with fighting against stupidity, hypocrisy, and repression. The article emphasizes LaVey's role in codifying life principles, making Satanism a sensible philosophy, and motivating his disciples to seek knowledge and embrace their 'plenitude'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Anton LaVey: The Transcendence of Fear
structure_content.summary: Chris Trian analyzes LaVey's philosophy as a method for transcending fear. Drawing from LaVey's background in carnival and wild animals, Trian argues that LaVey understood fear as the strongest motivator and a source of strength, and that his 'method' involved confronting fear and using humor as 'essential ether of the magician'.

Bob Johnson explores the post-LaVey future of the movement, cautioning against deifying LaVey and instead advocating for upholding the principles of Satanism. He argues that the focus should remain on self-empowerment and the practical application of LaVey's teachings rather than cult-like worship of the founder.

Blanche Barton outlines the path forward for the Church of Satan after LaVey's death, emphasizing its role as a 'bastion of reason and romance' that explores LaVey's ideas. She discusses the challenges of preserving the Black House and reiterates that Satanists are stratified by merit and ability, promoting continued dedication to individual passions and achievement as the best way to explain Satanism.

key_concepts.definition: A philosophy, founded by Anton LaVey, emphasizing self-indulgence, vital existence, reason, individualism, and personal responsibility, distinct from traditional religious worship, and focusing on the self as the highest being.

A spiritual or magical path focused on individual self-deification, personal accomplishment, and breaking societal norms and conventional morality, as opposed to self-surrender or subservience to a higher power.

Anton LaVey's historic Victorian residence in San Francisco, which served as the headquarters for the Church of Satan and a significant site for Satanic rituals and gatherings. Its preservation is highlighted as a post-LaVey challenge.

The practical application of magical principles to achieve real-world results, often through psychological manipulation, the cultivation of one's will, and a focus on tangible outcomes rather than purely symbolic or superstitious practices.

A concept attributed to LaVey emphasizing the deliberate creation of one's surroundings, filled with chosen objects and aesthetics, to isolate oneself from mundane influences and foster a magical, anachronistic lifestyle.

A conceptualization of Anton LaVey, and by extension the ideal Satanist, as embodying a powerful duality of refinement and grace combined with primal, 'bestial carnality,' rejecting sterile mediocrity.

practical_system.description: As conveyed through the collective testimonials, the practical system of LaVeyan Satanism centers on individual self-actualization and the deliberate application of philosophical tenets to achieve real-world results. It involves embracing one's 'carnal nature,' rejecting hypocrisy and victimhood, and living by 'self-made laws.' Practitioners are encouraged to develop personal strength, apply 'Lesser Magic' (psychological manipulation and strategic social interaction) and 'Greater Magic' (focused ritual for emotional release or self-transformation), and create 'Total Environments' to reinforce their will. The emphasis is on tangible, earthly success and personal fulfillment, making magic a pragmatic tool for living a vital and indulgent life, as exemplified by Anton LaVey himself.
tools: Black candles (for ritual ambiance and focus)
Organ/keyboards (for creating atmospheric or evocative music in ritual/personal practice)
Whoopee Cushion (used pragmatically in Lesser Magic/pranks)
Personal 'Total Environments' (deliberate arrangement of surroundings for psychological effect)
rituals: Messe Noir (Black Mass, for emotional and sensory indulgence)
Greater Magic (focused ritual for specific outcomes)

relevant_quotes.text: Death was the most unmemorable experience of my life.

There is no heaven of glory bright, and no hell where sinners roast. Here and now is our day of torment! Here and now is our day of joy! Here and now is our opportunity! Choose ye this day, this hour, for no redeemer liveth!
I don't think something is really magical unless it has a terrifying quality. In fact, anything that is good is a little frightening and is a little sad.
Living well is life's best revenge.
If it's a strong enough soul, the spirit will always be remembered.
Forget about morality, ethics, justice. Just remember, there are no rules!

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue is highly relevant for understanding the immediate historical and psychological impact of Anton LaVey's death on the Church of Satan and its followers. It provides a unique, first-hand look into how a modern esoteric movement navigates the loss of its charismatic founder, transitioning from a leader-centric model to a legacy-driven one. It reinforces LaVeyan Satanism's core principles as a philosophy of self-empowerment and pragmatic individualism, showcasing its continued vitality despite significant challenges. For scholars, it offers primary source material on the internal discourse and identity consolidation within a modern occult organization during a critical period.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of members and adherents of the Church of Satan, particularly those seeking reassurance, guidance, and community after Anton LaVey's death. It also appeals to individuals interested in LaVeyan Satanism, providing testimonials and philosophical insights. Academically, it is valuable for researchers and practitioners in Western Esotericism and Occultism, especially those studying modern Satanism, counter-cultural religious movements, and the dynamics of leadership and succession in esoteric groups.
